pain_points_original.title: Safeguarding Sensitive Government Data in AI
pain_points_original.description: The government needs to use AI without compromising sensitive information. The RFI demands vendors outline measures to "ensure the security and safeguarding of government data," a critical concern when integrating with third-party Large Language Models (LLMs) and handling public sector data.

pain_points_original.title: Ensuring Compliance with Government Policies
pain_points_original.description: Any AI solution must adhere to strict government regulations. This is a non-negotiable requirement, as any tool must comply with "Applicable ICT, Security and Cyber policies and South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) Instruction," posing a significant compliance risk.

pain_points_original.title: Boosting Inefficient Government Operations
pain_points_original.description: Existing processes are insufficient for meeting public service goals. The DPC is explicitly seeking AI to "boost efficiency, inform decision-making, and drive innovation" to improve service delivery, increase public satisfaction, and achieve better community outcomes.

pain_points_original.title: Integrating AI with Existing Government Systems
pain_points_original.description: The DPC faces the challenge of integrating modern AI tools with its existing, potentially legacy, infrastructure. They need to "assess the maturity, scalability, and adaptability of vendor solutions that may be suitable for integration into existing government systems" to avoid technical failure.

pain_points_original.title: Uncertainty of AI Solution Costs for Budgeting
pain_points_original.description: The department lacks the financial data needed to plan for AI adoption. A key goal is to "Obtain indicative costing models and pricing structures to inform future procurement planning and budget allocation," which is a critical prerequisite for any future investment.

pain_points_original.title: Lack of AI Market and Technology Understanding
pain_points_original.description: The DPC has a knowledge gap about the current AI landscape, creating a risk of choosing suboptimal solutions. The RFI's purpose is to "gain a better understanding of the current landscape of AI tools, solutions, and services" to create a 'catalogue of offerings' for future planning.

pain_points_original.title: De-risking AI Adoption via Real-World Trials
pain_points_original.description: The government wants to avoid costly failed implementations by validating solutions before full-scale adoption. They need to "explore opportunities for ... pilot initiatives, allowing government agencies to trial AI solutions in real-world scenarios" to mitigate investment risk.

pain_points_original.title: Avoiding Common AI Deployment Pitfalls
pain_points_original.description: Recognizing their potential inexperience, the DPC seeks to avoid predictable implementation mistakes. They want to "Learn from vendors' experiences in deploying AI solutions within similar sectors or government contexts, including lessons learned and best practices."
